New Records: Yoshinobu Yamamoto and Yu Darvish were the first Japanese-born starting pitchers to square off in major league playoff history.
The Padres and Dodgers combined to retire 26 consecutive batters — the longest streak in a single game in postseason history.
Key Match Events: Yoshinobu Yamamoto outdueled Yu Darvish, allowing two hits over five innings for the win.
Kiké Hernández and Teoscar Hernández hit home runs for the Dodgers.
Evan Phillips, Alex Vesia, Michael Kopech, and Blake Treinen provided stellar bullpen support.
The Dodgers retired the last 19 Padres batters.
Teoscar Hernández’s homer chased Darvish in the seventh inning.
The Dodgers staved off elimination with an 8-0 victory in Game 4 to force the deciding game back home.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers signed Yoshinobu Yamamoto to a $325 million, 12-year deal and Shohei Ohtani to a record $700 million, 10-year contract in the offseason.
Post-Match Reflections: Freddie Freeman expressed happiness with the win.
Manager Dave Roberts stated, 'We’re ready for the next level.'
Mookie Betts reflected on the team's resilience and underdog status.
Andrew Friedman, president of baseball operations, commented on overcoming a 'DS funk.'
Padres manager Mike Shildt described the loss as 'stunning.'
Yu Darvish praised Yamamoto, calling him a great pitcher and human being.
Yamamoto expressed pride in pitching on a global stage for Japan.
Mookie Betts commented on the celebratory atmosphere, saying, 'Anytime you’re smelling like champagne, it means you’re doing something good.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers advanced to the National League Championship Series to play the New York Mets.
The game was attended by celebrities including LeBron James, Brad Pitt, Rob Lowe, Bryan Cranston, and Jimmy Kimmel.
The Dodgers won a decisive Game 5 at home for the first time since 1981.
The public-address announcer warned fans not to throw objects or go on the field during the game.
